title: Friday, 2nd June, 2017
bodyHTML:
10:59 am
IK11:00am

Good morning everyone! That's now three days on the trott starting just before 11....

IK11:00am

Hello Kadhim

KS11:00am

It's our last day Izzy

11:00 am
IK11:01am

yes, sad face

KS11:01am

Bryce returns next week

IK11:01am

Cry smile

11:00 am
KS11:01am

Cry smileCry smileCry smile

IK11:01am

But i have to report, our commander and chief -- the great Paul Murphy -- did alert us to his presence yesterday.

IK11:02am

He's off on sabbatical but made a comment fly-by to suppress rumoutrage about his political persuasions.

11:02 am
IK11:03am

This was on the back off general team posturing over what non FTAV people think FTAV people think about politics.

KS11:03am

We all think it's, on balance, a bad thing

KS11:03am

Lemme get a picture up

11:03 am
KS11:03am

KS11:03am

A New Yorker classic

KS11:04am

In honour of the news that Trump is pulling the US out of the Paris climate accord

11:04 am
KS11:04am

Which has annoyed everyone, even Musk

KS11:04am

Who, hilariously, wrote this last week

KS11:04am

https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/866798148303200256

11:04 am
KS11:05am

People still haven't figured out... that they have, at most, fleeting influence on Trump

KS11:05am

You have to be a fool or a masochist to make any public statement on the basis of what Trump may or may not have promised you

IK11:05am

So on Musk being annoyed... quelle shoque. Here's a president who might actually force him to run a company based on meritocracy rather than a subsidy framework.

11:05 am
IK11:05am

So i'm going to dissent... (as usual)

IK11:06am

Not because i don't believe in climate action. I DO! but i also believe in other existential threats likes runaway killer AI, where are the tech moratoriums eh?

IK11:06am

Anyway, here's Reuters John Kemp on the Paris pull out, an important point

11:06 am
IK11:06am

President Trump’s statement on withdrawing from the Paris climate accord is a must-read, whether you agree with decision or not. The statement shows a lot of careful drafting. This was not an impromptu decision. The logic and communications were thought through carefully by the White House staff, again whether you agree with it or not. The statement is the clearest articulation so far of the administration’s fundamental economic, diplomatic and energy strategy.

IK11:06am

Here's the actual statement

IK11:06am

https://www.whiteh...ris-climate-accord

11:07 am
IK11:07am

Whether you love Trump or hate him, i think this point here is not crazy

IK11:07am

This agreement is less about the climate and more about other countries gaining a financial advantage over the United States. The rest of the world applauded when we signed the Paris Agreement -- they went wild; they were so happy -- for the simple reason that it put our country, the United States of America, which we all love, at a very, very big economic disadvantage. A cynic would say the obvious reason for economic competitors and their wish to see us remain in the agreement is so that we continue to suffer this self-inflicted major economic wound. We would find it very hard to compete with other countries from other parts of the world.

IK11:07am

We all love america don't we?

11:07 am
KS11:07am

.....

KS11:07am

I have to say I disagree in the strongest terms about that point not being crazy...

KS11:07am

But let's get on

11:07 am
undefined
IK11:08am

So... RocketRocket

IK11:09am

FTSE100

IK11:09am

We have to confess, we are a bit rubbish with the automaton codes

IK11:09am

so you get a manual print out

IK11:10am

High of 7,598.99

11:09 am
KS11:10am

(@lefevre: whynotboth.jpg)

IK11:10am

woo hoo

KS11:10am

\O/

11:10 am
KS11:10am

what's driving that?

IK11:10am

@patience - err, have you not seen Terminator 2???

IK11:11am

@patience -- it's a very good documentary,

11:10 am
IK11:11am

Anyway back to the FTSE

IK11:11am

All round good sentiment. Europe too. A bunch of solid manufacturing data etc

IK11:13am

11:14 am

But in the mean time there is this from FastFT

IK11:14am

https://www.ft.com...-a157-0bb856d4c096

KS11:14am

tut tut, bryce would never lose the commentary

11:14 am
IK11:15am

Activity in the UK’s construction sector beat forecasts for the second month in a row in May, according to a key survey of the sector which suggests growth is picking up after a weak start to the year.

The purchasing managers’ index for the sector – which accounts for around 6 per cent of economic output – came in at 56, compared to the previous month’s 53.1.

Economists had expected the figure to slide to 52.6, but a sharp increase in residential work meant companies were more optimistic than had been predicted.

KS11:15am

Brexit: good for manufacturing, bad for probably everything else

IK11:15am

Anyway what's leading are the banks

11:16 am
Standard Chartered PLC (STAN:LSE): Last: 758.60, up 13.8 (+1.85%), High: 759.90, Low: 747.80, Volume: 2.17m
Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS:LSE): Last: 263.30, up 4.4 (+1.70%), High: 264.10, Low: 260.00, Volume: 2.57m

Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 1,022, down 12.5 (-1.21%), High: 1,052, Low: 1,021, Volume: 2.07m
11:17 am

IK11:17am

So let's move on to some corp news we can give valid insight on

IK11:17am

Kadhim ...

11:17 am
undefined
IK11:18am

your favourite bank

KS11:18am

Metro Bank

11:18 am
Metro Bank PLC (MTRO:LSE): Last: 3,795, up 76 (+2.04%), High: 3,805, Low: 3,695, Volume: 25.59k
KS11:18am

Bought a bunch of buy to let mortgages off of Cerberus

KS11:18am

Here's Jefferies to explain

11:18 am
KS11:19am

(in generally positive terms)

KS11:19am

£600m of mortgage loans purchased from Cerberus. MTRO has announced today that it completed the purchase of a £596.7m portfolio of UK mortgages from Cerberus European Residential Holdings BV. 92% of the book is buy-to-let mortgage, has a weighted average seasoning of c.10 years, with an average loan-to-value of 70%.

Deploying sub-LIBOR funds and driving loans/deposits to 78%. The core element of our investment thesis on MTRO is that the bank's cleverer business model generates sticky relationship-based deposits whose cost has been - and ought to sustainably remain - below LIBOR. To wit, in 1Q17, MTRO's average cost of deposits was 61bps against an average LIBOR of 75bps. Today, MTRO puts this low-cost funding to work, growing its loan book by 9% to £7.1bn and implying a pro forma loan/deposit ratio of 78% (v 72% at 1Q and a 2020 target of 80%). The "pay rate" on the acquired book is 1.6% linked to the BOE base rate.

KS11:19am

The reason to mention is this goes to the whole Metro Bank model

11:19 am
KS11:19am

Which is basically a carbon copy of chairman Vernon Hill's previous venture in the US, Commerce Bank

KS11:20am

Loans don't matter, deposits do

KS11:20am

Hoover up deposits, and let the asset side of the balance sheet catch up, which ever way it can

11:20 am
KS11:20am

(including buying loans wholesale from the likes of Cerberus)

KS11:20am

final little bit from Jefferies

KS11:20am

Limited detail on terms. The company has provided limited detail on terms of the transaction, other than to disclose that the book is being acquired from cash resources at a discount to par (which makes sense to us given the 1.6% pay rate). While terms were not disclosed, we believe it is likely that MTRO would have sought a transaction that is accretive to earnings.

11:20 am
KS11:20am

Nice bit of optimism there

KS11:21am

'We don't know the terms, but we assume management did a good deal'

IK11:25am

Run rate revenue said to be ahead of Q1’17 ($77.5m). Profit margin said to have been maintained. Q1’17 EBITDA margin was 59%. One month left to run but by implication, H1’17 revenue should be at least $155m and EBITDA $92m. Our current CY17 EBITDA forecast is $110m. Impact of FCA review still unknown for H2’17 and beyond. However, clearly significant upside risk to forecasts, particularly for CY17. We shall review TP and forecasts accordingly.

Plus500 Ltd (PLUS:LSE): Last: 558.17, up 39.16 (+7.55%), High: 582.00, Low: 524.00, Volume: 1.08m

@residual - i am all for cross-subsidisation as long as it's sustainable. Unbundling is the big trend at the moment, and i am just very sceptical that these services can be unbundled all that easily because of all the legacy cross-subsidisation

Google news

KS11:27am

11:27 am
KS11:27am

They're introducing an "ad-filter"

KS11:28am

KS11:28am

11:27 am

11:28 am
KS11:28am

https://www.ft.com...-8519-9f94ee97d996

KS11:28am

The internet company is launching “funding choices” where publishers can set a price per page view for consumers using ad blockers to pay — or abandon their blockers and see the ads. Google will track how many pages people view and charge them through a new version of their Google Contributor service.

KS11:29am

So... on the one hand, existing ad blocking tools are going to hit by this new tool

11:29 am
KS11:29am

And there'll be a new, Google approved alternative option

KS11:29am

Sounds... a bit like a market leader using their power to push out the competition

KS11:30am

Chrome, Google's browser, is the leading web browser after all

11:30 am
IK11:30am

You know how i feel about this Kadhim. If it's free you're the product. Sadly, I don't think we have the economic standing to be able to afford neutral non-ad funded news. And if ad blockers continue to offer those services for free, they'll get the users.

KS11:30am

Except they won't

KS11:30am

Coz everyone uses Chrome

11:30 am
KS11:30am

And now there'll be an inbuilt thing in Chrome

KS11:30am

KS11:31am

11:31 am

11:40 am
IK11:41am

“House prices recorded their third consecutive monthly fall in May – the first time this has occurred since 2009. The annual rate of growth slowed to 2.1%, the weakest in almost four years.

“It is still early days, but this provides further evidence that the housing market is losing momentum. Moreover, this may be indicative of a wider slowdown in the household sector, though data continues to send mixed signals in this regard.

“While real incomes are again coming under pressure as inflation has overtaken wage growth, the number of people in work has continued to rise at a healthy pace. Indeed, the unemployment rate fell to a 42-year low in the three months to March.

“If history is any guide, the slowdown is unlikely to be linked to election-related uncertainty. Housing market trends have not traditionally been impacted around the time of general elections. Rightly or wrongly, for most home buyers, elections are not foremost in their minds while buying or selling their home.

11:53 am
IK11:53am

So i'm just going to give the analyst views

IK11:53am

Here's Deutsche

IK11:53am

Welcome to another payrolls Friday. DB expects a well above consensus 235k print (market at 182k) which Joe LaVorgna notes is supported by a strong 253k ADP print yesterday. He thinks there was evidence of retail jobs stabilising in the report after a difficult period for the sector. Other reasons for Joe's call is that the four-week moving average of jobless claims during the May survey period was 241k, which was the lowest for any employment survey week since July 1973 (240k). Also he argues that withheld income tax receipts are tracking up close to 7% compared to a year ago, which points to rising income growth. Since tax receipts are a direct function of employment, hours and wages, the recent acceleration in income growth should at least partly be reflected in the pace of job gains. Joe remains less confident in wages, where the growth rate remains soft relative to the sub-5% level of the unemployment rate. After some recent data apathy if Joe is right on payrolls there will be some renewed excitement in markets.

11:53 am
IK11:54am

Here's Unicredit...

IK11:54am

US (I): Nonfarm payrolls likely rose another solid 175k in May (after 211k in April), in line with the average payroll gain seen over the past three or six months. The jobless rate is expected to remain stable at 4.4%, which matches the cyclical low reached during the height of the housing boom (14:30 CET).

IK11:54am

Here's RBC ...

11:54 am
IK11:54am

USD: The most relevant and timely “hard data” on the employment front suggests that job growth continued to hum along in May. Our US economists note that initial jobless claims are still plumbing the depths near all-time lows (LF-adjusted), but also that withheld tax receipts (the stuff that comes out of your paycheck) are running near 7% above year-ago levels. This suggests that not only is firing extremely limited, but paychecks are increasing (firming headcount, increased pay, or some combination thereof). Accordingly, we expect headline and private NFP to come in at 200K for the month. The unemployment rate should remain unchanged at 4.4% following a sharp tick lower last month. The consensus expectation for payrolls has firmed after the ADP report yesterday (205K for the forecasts that have been revised compared to 182K for all forecasts).

IK11:55am

so there's quite a range in the forecasts
